sen.j: 鎌倉幕府と自由任官の禁止
sen.e: Kamakura bakufu and the prohibition of free appointments (Jiyuninkan)

sen.cmt: 「自由任官」は「幕府を介さず朝廷から直接任官」の意なので、"direct apointments"としました。
sen.e: Kamakura bakufu and the prohibition of direct appointments (Jiyuninkan)

sen.j: 鎌倉時代以降、鎌倉幕府の御家人たる武士の叙位任官は鎌倉殿を通じて朝廷に具申することを原則として、御家人が直接的に朝廷から叙位任官を受けることを厳禁とした。
sen.e: Since the Kamakura period, as a general rule, the samurai who became shogunal retainers reported via the lord of Kamakura about the conferment of a court rank and appointment to an office to the Imperial Court. For the shogunal retainers it was strictly prohibited to receive a rank and office directly from the Imperial Court.

Since the Kamakura period, as a general rule, the conferments of a court rank and appointment to an office of samurai who were shogunal retainers were reported to the Imperial Court via the lord of Kamakura, and it was strictly prohibited for the shogunal retainers to receive a rank and office directly from the Imperial Court.

Since the Kamakura period, as a general rule, the conferments of a court rank and appointment to an office of samurai who were shogunal retainers were reported to the Imperial Court via the lord of Kamakura, and it was strictly prohibited for the shogunal retainers to receive a rank and office directly from the Imperial Court.

sen.j: これは、御家人の主人はあくまで幕府主宰者たる鎌倉殿であり、御家人が直接的に朝廷と関わりを持つことは、御家人の離反や自立などの事態を招く危険もあり、これを予防する意味があった。
sen.e: It was intended to prevent shogunal retainers to have direct relation with the Imperial Court because the master of shogunal retainers were the lord of kamakura, who held the bakufu, and the bakufu feared that direct relation between shogunal retainers and the Imperial Court might lead to estrangement or independence of shogunal retainers.

sen.j: この禁を破り、御家人が鎌倉幕府を介せず、または許しを得ることなく、叙位任官することを自由任官という。
sen.e: When this prohibition was violated and a shogunal retainer received a rank or post without involving the Kamakura shogunate and without permission, that is called Jiyuninkan.

sen.e: In order to put appointments of posts (ninkan) under the control of the shogun a commissioner was set up in the shogunate, who acted as a contact for samurai families (buke), who applied for ninkan.
